The DEA considers any use of kratom abuse, and this is not fair to the people who use it, nor is it logical. Do we consider drinking a cup of coffee in the morning abuse, or having a beer after work abuse? Why is it that ingesting these substances is okay, but consuming a certain plant is not? What makes society okay with consuming certain substances, but not others? These decisions are not made based upon logic, the true harm to a person or society at large, or science; they are based upon  opinions and arbitrary decisions.

Kratom is an internationally recognized dietary supplement, and to be concerned about why kratom is used is akin to asking why some people consume a vitamin C tablet; this should be a personal choice, and a liberty. Kratom's alkaloids are also well-tolerated. This has been demonstrated in the literature; although kratom's alkaloids bind to opioid receptors, kratom does not cause the respiratory depression and the harmful effects of traditional opioids. Babu, McCurdy, and Boyer state: "Although mitragynines agonize mu-opioid receptors, respiratory 
depression, coma, pulmonary edema and death have not, to our knowledge, 
been associated with human kratom ingestion" (Babu, McCurdy & Boyer,
2008). Ward and colleagues write: "Adverse effects from kratom are
limited. Kratom use does not appear to be associated with the emesis
that commonly accompanies opioid use. Interestingly, respiratory
depression following kratom administration has not been observed" (Ward,
Rosenbaum, Hernon, McCurdy & Boyer, 2011). De Moraes and others state:
"In addition, MIT [mitragynine]causes much less 
respiratory depression and does not produce emesis or dyspnea when 
compared to other opioids" (De Maoraes, Moretti, Furr, McCurdy &
Lanchote, 2009). The DEA claims that deaths have resulted in kratom ingestion, yet it cannot provide an instance in which kratom was the only contributing factor. All the deaths and adverse health reactions that are claimed to be from kratom alone have been the result of poly-drug intoxication. For instance, an article entitled "Seizure and Coma
Following Kratom (Mitragynina speciosa Korth) Exposure" (Nelsen et al.,
2010) states the following: "[The] patient had ingested a tea made with kratom and Datura
stramonium." Furthermore: "Urine drug screening was positive for cannabinoids, tricyclic antidepressants, and oxycodone." Just because kratom's alkaloids were found in the blood of deceased or ill subjects is not a reason to claim that kratom alone was responsible.

Placing kratom's alkaloids into schedule I will have many consequences. Research into safer alternatives to traditional opioid medications will be severely hampered. People who rely on kratom for a better quality of life will no longer be able to obtain it legally. People who use kratom to manage debilitating health conditions and chronic pain will endure needless suffering. Folks who use kratom to manage opioid addiction will go back to more dangerous substances. American citizens who want nothing more than the liberty to use a safe and effective dietary supplement will be turned into felons. People who could have contributed to society will sit behind bars, not because they were violent, not because they harmed another person, but because they possessed a leaf from Southeast Asia; surely the legal system has more pressing priorities than this. Society will not benefit from outlawing kratom; the result will be a worsening opioid epidemic, restricted freedom, needless suffering, a higher burden on the legal system, and lack of research which could lead the way to safer medications. The DEA should be focusing on fentanyl analogues from China, the heroin which is of higher quality and cheaper than it ever has been, the lethal designer drugs and chemicals that are untested and unsafe; kratom has been used for thousands of years in Southeast Asia with no harm to those who choose to ingest it. Kratom is not harmful, and to ban it is a vastly misguided and gratuitous attempt at solving a problem; kratom is not the cause of this problem, in fact it holds the capacity to greatly benefit society in a myriad of ways.
